Award.AwardTitle: Molecular dynamics simulations of chemical reactions and interactions at liquid interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ilan Benjamin of the University of California Santa Cruz is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for research to develop molecular dynamics techniques for the simulation of liquid-liquid interfaces. Two different processes are being considered: photoinduced electron transfer at liquid-liquid interfaces; and phase transfer catalyzed SN2 reactions at liquid-liquid interfaces.

Many chemical reactions of importance to diverse fields such as environmental sciences, energy storage and catalysis occur at liquid interfaces. To understand the influence of the interface region on chemical reactivity, a molecularly detailed understanding of these systems is required. Advances in surface-specific experimental techniques have provided numerous new results on the spectroscopy and reactivity of chemical species at liquid interfaces. While these have helped gain valuable insight into the nature of molecular interactions at liquid interfaces, the vast complexity of the interfacial region requires complimentary progress in the theoretical modeling and understanding of these systems. This work is havintg a broader impact by providing a fundamental understanding of the effect of the liquid interface region on chemical reactivity. It is having a further broad impact through the education and training of students involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funds supported our computational work aimed at understanding chemical reactivity at liquid interfaces, specifically at the water/oil interface. The motivation is to answer fundamental questions about molecular interactions in heterogeneous liquid media, which then can be used to address several important technological and environmental issues. Liquid interfaces and surfaces are extremely challenging systems to study because of the difficulty of obtaining and interpreting experimental data and the complexity of theoretical statistical mechanical treatments.  Computer simulations are thus ideal tools for gaining insight into the behavior of reactive and non-reactive solutes in these systems. The specific projects undertaken provided new molecular-level understanding of systems that have been studied experimentally, thus enabling us to test our theoretical understanding and predictions.

 

Specific outcomes of our work included:

 

1. Our model calculations on nucleophilic substitution reactions at the interface between water and chloroform suggest routes for optimization of phase transfer catalysts. These catalysts are important in the design on environmentally safe approaches to the synthesis of new chemicals used in the pharmaceutical and agrochemical industries.

 

2. Our work on ion transport and adsorption at electrochemical liquid/liquid interfaces (some in collaboration with Schlossman’s group at the university of Illinois in Chicago) provides insight into the structure of charged interfaces and the limitation of continuum models in describing this structure. These interfaces are of fundamental importance in many areas of science and technology (biomembranes, batteries, mineral surfaces, and more).

 

3. We developed a theoretical framework to study electron transfer reactions initiated by light absorption at the liquid/liquid interface. Our calculations were in good agreement with pioneering new experiments (carried out by the Eisenthal group at Columbia University, NY) that were able for the first time to provide accurate values for interfacial electron transfer reactions. Our approach can be used to study electron transfer at biological membranes and is also important for understanding key processes involved in solar energy conversion.
